tips.tip: Success story: Patient MAC-free since May 2021 after 22 months azithromycin, ethambutol & Arikayce - normal PFT, stable CT, twice-daily airway clearance routine, accepts possibility of reinfection without letting it control life
tips.notes: Mamie Balestra: 'My definition of success story is constant adaptation to what life throws my way.' Uses LifeStraw water, Aqua Tools shower filter or baths, probiotics, turmeric. Focuses on family, friends, faith, nature, art. Attitude: will be disappointed if reinfected, then adapt again.

tips.tip: Long-term success stories exist: patients clear for 5-8+ years (2009, 2019 clearance) - but many stay vigilant with airway clearance even after negative cultures since vulnerability remains due to underlying bronchiectasis
tips.notes: Multiple success stories: Patient clear since 2009 after 3 rounds treatment over 6 years (2001, 2004, 2007 diagnoses). Another clear since 2019 after back-to-back MAC/chimaera causing 2 years bedridden. Doctor notes 'very few' patients continue diligent airway clearance post-treatment - this may explain high reinfection rates.

tips.tip: Working full-time with NTM is challenging but possible - requires supportive employer, work-from-home flexibility, time efficiencies (outsource laundry/cleaning), cutting back exercise slightly, and accepting career may suffer
tips.notes: Patients working 40-60 hours/week report: 2-3 hours daily AC, struggle to fit everything in, 6 hours sleep on 12-hour shifts, resentment about time burden, career suffering. Remote work huge help - no commuting, appearance prep, or gas station stops. Single business owner: electric car (Tesla), Trader Joe's shortcuts, listen to audiobooks during AC. Hospital ER nurse: 3 hours AC daily, husband helps cooking/chores, strong work ethic pushes through.

tips.tip: Social Security Disability qualification difficult - typically requires: (1) Not working 12 months due to condition, (2) Lung function 40% or lower - many symptomatic patients don't qualify, creating financial stress
tips.notes: Patient 'let go' after repeated pneumonia 4-5x/year got SSD approved at 61. Another's SSD pending over 1 year with repetitive paperwork. Private long-term disability approved 3 weeks then abruptly denied. Medicare at 65 caused employer to drop insurance 'like hot potato.' Need for income vs inability to work creates crisis for working-age patients.

tips.tip: Starting 'Big 3' antibiotics: many patients have NO or minimal side effects (orange pee, tooth discoloration, fatigue, itchy skin) - fear often worse than reality, but outcomes highly individual ranging from 'breezed through' to 'horrible, had to stop'
tips.notes: Multiple positive reports: no side effects, able to do everything normally, took at night before bed. Tooth discoloration resolved with daily hydrogen peroxide rinse. Ondansetron (Zofran 4mg dissolvable) critical for nausea/GI issues during adjustment. Switching to every-other-day dosing helped some. Age/general health/infection load affect tolerance. Online reports skewed negative - people with NO problems don't post.

tips.tip: Many asymptomatic patients discovered through incidental findings (broken elbow X-ray, routine cardiac scan, breast cancer workup) struggle with 'should I treat?' decision - some choose watch-and-wait with twice-daily nebulizer if CT stable
tips.notes: 73-year-old patient: nodules grew, diagnosed MAC/BE/possibly CF/possibly RA, 100 lbs, NO symptoms except slight fatigue. NJH prescribed nebulizer 2x/day, weight gain, upright sleep, recheck in 6 months. Chose NOT to take drugs for quality of life. Others: 61-year-old discovered on cardiac scan, 78-year-old managing with AC only, 75-year-old using chest percussion 2x/day (no drugs). All emphasize quality vs quantity decision. Article: 'Hesitation Blues' on treat-or-not dilemma.

tips.tip: Diagnosis process varies widely: some start treatment immediately after single bronchoscopy, others required to provide 3 sputum samples despite positive bronch - CDC criteria: 2 positive sputa OR 1 positive bronchoscopy sufficient for diagnosis
tips.notes: Patient frustrated: bronchoscopy showed E. coli, NTM avium, NTM abscessus but doctor required 3 sputum samples before treatment (only 1 of 3 showed tiny E. coli, no NTM). CDC criteria clear: https://www.cdc.gov/nontuberculous-mycobacteria/hcp/clinical-overview/ says 2 positive sputa OR 1 positive bronch sufficient. Decision to treat depends on CT results + symptoms, not just positive cultures.

tips.tip: National Jewish Health 2-week evaluation provides comprehensive testing beyond CT scans/cultures - 42+ tests including genetic causes of susceptibility, strain-specific drug sensitivity, underlying conditions - critical for treatment planning
tips.notes: Patient: 'NJH does far more than CTs and growing cultures - battery of tests to determine WHY susceptible (health issues, genetics), which medications work with your specific bacteria strands.' After 2 years local care (pulmonologist, ID specialist, surgeon), referred to NJH. Results: 42 tests (didn't understand), pending cystic fibrosis test, recommendation: nebulizer 2x/day with 7% saline, vaccines, weight gain, watch and wait. Life-long NJH connection ensures best care.

tips.tip: M. abscessus treatment brutal but can work: 9-week hospital IV intensive phase + 12-18 months continuation (daily drugs, twice-daily Amikacin nebulizer, monthly checkups, hearing tests, ECGs, biweekly bloods) - patient swimming 3km 5x/week, dreadful cough gone
tips.notes: M. abscessus subspecies abscessus erm 41 most drug-resistant. New Zealand patient: week 58 of treatment, fit and well, recently traveled UK/Europe, no hearing issues, tolerated all drugs except one (changed). Another patient: 14 months treatment 8 years ago (2 IV, 3 oral), dropped 2 drugs due to toxic side effects including hearing loss (devastating), treatment worked but reinfected. Reluctant to retreat due to hearing risk. Delayed 6 years initially since feeling well.

tips.tip: NTM fatigue is debilitating disease symptom (not just medication side effect) - patients bedridden 2 years, unable to empty dishwasher, exhausted after airway clearance - improves with treatment (12-18 months) or regular AC alone, exercise transformative
tips.notes: Patient bedridden 2 years with back-to-back MAC/chimaera (2018-2019), now swimming half mile daily 6 years post-treatment. Another: fatigue took 1.5 years antibiotics to improve, another 4 months. Pulmonary rehab: 'unable to empty dishwasher to jogging on treadmill in 6 weeks.' Patient with RA + BE: airway clearance itself exhausting - inflammation from both + extra breathing effort. One requires 10 hours sleep nightly, believes Pseudomonas causes fatigue. Exercise helps even when don't feel like it.

tips.tip: Diagnostic errors common: 1 in 10 diagnoses wrong/delayed/missed, NTM patients frequently misdiagnosed as asthma or walking pneumonia initially - prescribed contraindicated treatments, some dying before correct diagnosis due to lung damage
tips.notes: JAMA article: 'Deaths related to diagnostic error common; roughly 1 in 10 diagnoses wrong, egregiously delayed, or missed. National Academy of Medicine concluded each of us likely to have diagnostic error in lifetime.' Patient personally knows case died from misdiagnosis - lungs too damaged by time correctly diagnosed. Another told 'treatment worse than disease' for years while MAC destroyed lingula, told 'didn't look sick,' pulmonologist at prestigious medical school refused NJH referral claiming equal expertise. Patient self-referred.

tips.tip: Attitude matters: patients emphasize 'constant adaptation to what life throws my way,' focus on what you love (family, friends, faith, nature, art), don't let disease define you - easier said than done, especially first year, but trying to stay positive helps
tips.notes: 73-year-old retired woman horrified first year, cavity developed, depressing. NJH clinicians: 'could live relatively normal life, staying positive really helps.' Cavity closed, still MAI positive but living life: 'gave one year to disease, will do less than dreamed but carrying on.' Won't let water management drive her crazy - does what makes sense, won't be driven crazy. 78-year-old: 'life is like cancer, strong element of luck/genetics, do what we can, leave rest to God.'

tips.tip: Watch-and-wait approach valid for asymptomatic/mild disease: twice-daily nebulizer with 7% saline, regular CT monitoring, exercise, weight management - some patients stable 8-10+ years without antibiotics using aggressive airway clearance
tips.notes: 78-year-old diagnosed 2020 with MAI (3 cultures), fairly stable, NYU Langone Bronchiectasis/NTM center, chest percussion + breathing techniques 2x/day, doctor not pushing antibiotics since CT 'mild,' patient ultra-sensitive to meds. 85-year-old mother told MAC in 60s, never took drugs, has COPD but quite healthy at 85. 70-year-old: nebulizer 2x/day, 4 negative MAC tests, CT nodules stable, recent heavy Pseudomonas growth prompted 3-week IV ceftazidime. Will NEVER do MAC Big 3 - 'too toxic, body can't handle.'

tips.tip: First year after diagnosis hardest emotionally - overwhelming, scary, depressing - patients experience stages: denial, anger, grief, then gradual acceptance and adaptation as learn to manage disease
tips.notes: Patient: 'first year was hard, problems with meds, developed cavity, scary and depressing.' Another: 'totally agree with Mamie, attitude really important, easier said than done especially at first.' Forum consensus: 'this difficult disease to manage medically AND emotionally, no doubt, can bring strongest person to knees at times. Acknowledgement of this fact just as important as support and pats on back.' New diagnoses: 'grateful for this group helping deal with NTM, empathy for each other in fight is so healing.'

tips.tip: Working with NTM requires ruthless prioritization: batch-clean equipment while doing other kitchen tasks, get vest qualification (wear while working), use AC time for audiobooks/emails, schedule hearing tests/ECGs during work hours if employer flexible
tips.notes: Small business owner: microwave bags for sterilizing (after Dawn wash), baby bottle sterilizer next investment, wash in batches in kitchen while doing other things. Vest game-changer: wear while working, no focus needed, minimal cleaning. Morning AC before work starts, evening AC last 30 minutes work day if no speaking calls. Schedule 2-3 hours AC by waking earlier or staying up later. ER nurse: 42 years work ethic, 3 hours AC daily, husband helps chores, 6 hours sleep on 12-hour shifts.

tips.tip: Traveling with M. abscessus treatment possible: patient on week 58 of treatment traveled UK/Europe from New Zealand while on daily drugs + twice-daily Amikacin nebulizer - requires planning but doable
tips.notes: M. abscessus subsp abscessus erm 41 patient: traveled internationally while on continuation phase (post-9-week hospital intensive phase). Swimming 3km 5x/week, walking/stretching daily, monthly team check-ins, hearing tests, ECGs, biweekly bloods. Dreadful cough gone. 'Life is good.' Demonstrates treatment doesn't mean house-bound.

tips.tip: Younger working patients (50-65) face unique challenge: too young to retire, need insurance, career prime years disrupted - consider joining 50-and-under support group for relatable experiences
tips.notes: 55-year-old: '100 of last 120 days missed work, employer unsupportive, single with mortgage, creative accounting for survival, 64 but can't retire.' 58-year-old post-lung-cancer-lobectomy can't tell which symptoms from surgery vs MAC: 'I am young and healthy - what a joke! My lungs are my life now.' Support group for 50-and-under exists - members work full-time, more relatable than retiree-dominated general groups. Financial stress + physical demands unique to working-age patients.

tips.tip: Exercise transformative for fatigue and mental health even when don't feel like it - pulmonary rehab can progress from 'unable to empty dishwasher' to 'jogging on treadmill' in 6 weeks with tiny incremental steps
tips.notes: Patient: 'absolutely, fatigue is symptom, apart from sleep/nutrition, exercise really helps - you won't feel like it, you are ill and tired, but honestly if you get started it's transformative, look for support from personal trainer or exercise group, build in tiny steps.' Patient working full-time with 2 large labs walks dogs several times daily + yoga most days: 'maintaining normal day-to-day important for mental health, then chill on weekends.' Another: swimming, yoga, barre, Pilates, Peloton - 'exercise is form of AC, would rather be moving than tethered to nebulizer.'

tips.tip: Reinfection rates high (less than 30% MAC-free for life per Mayo Clinic) - contributing factors likely include: not everyone continues diligent airway clearance post-treatment, underlying bronchiectasis vulnerability, environmental ubiquity of bacteria, possible bacterial dormancy/re-emergence theory
tips.notes: Dr. Timothy Mayo Clinic: 'less than 30% patients MAC-free whole life.' Doctor to patient: 'very few continue lung clearance diligently after successful drug treatment.' Theory: not new variant but original mycobacterium remained dormant in lungs, re-emerged. Patient 22 years: MAC 2002, Abscessus 2012, Abscessus-Abscessus with macrolide resistance 2024, now testing negative 1 year, off meds 2 weeks, 'probably got careless,' religiously does AC. Vulnerability remains even with treatment success.

tips.tip: Genetics and underlying conditions play major role in treatment tolerance - factors like age, general health, MTHFR mutation, autoimmune diseases, Crohn's, infection load all affect Big 3 side effects and treatment decisions
tips.notes: Patient with Crohn's: antibiotics even 1-2 weeks 'reeks havoc,' petrified of C. diff reliving. Multiple patients: 'I am the one to get side effects, it's my genetic stuff,' MTHFR homozygous. 73-year-old: 'often experience side effects from medications, greatly suspect antibiotics would be significant for me,' possibly CF, possibly RA. NJH testing evaluates genetic susceptibility. Forum request: would help to know respondent age, general health, infection load when assessing treatment experience relevance.

tips.tip: Newly diagnosed patients with active lifestyles (hiking, biking, kayaking, RV camping) can continue outdoor activities with smart precautions: N95 masks for dusty trails/muddy conditions, portable nebulizers for travel, 0.2 micron water filters, masking near waterfalls
tips.notes: 64-year-old diagnosed with BE + MAC, healthy/active lifestyle with camper van. Multiple hikers continue: Appalachian Trail (245 miles), Acadia, Algonquin, Grand Canyon, Bryce Canyon, Zion, Machu Picchu, Galapagos. Patients report: N95 masks in pocket for muddy/dusty trails and waterfalls, portable nebulizers (OMRON NE-U100 battery-operated, Pari S Trek rechargeable), Sawyer Squeeze 0.2 micron filter for trail water removes NTM. Travel trailer upgrade from tent for Arikayce refrigeration. Quality: hiking/biking good for lungs despite risks - risk management approach. One camper 3-week Italy trip, 6-week RV trip post-NJH visit.

tips.tip: Starting airway clearance after new diagnosis overwhelming but becomes routine - takes 30-60 minutes per session, twice daily, juggling equipment cleaning/sterilization adds time burden but essential habit for stability
tips.notes: Newly diagnosed patients describe: 'never knew I had this so airway clearance all new,' 'super overwhelmed in beginning with all info,' struggle finding time especially while working full-time. Reality: nebulizing + vest/Aerobika + postural drainage + cleaning equipment takes significant daily time. Portable options help: battery-operated nebulizers, travel-size equipment. Some wait 6 months trying AC before deciding on antibiotics. Equipment: Ombra compressor, Pari Vios, AeroEclipse/Pari Sprint nebulizers, AffloVest, SmartVest, Aerobika, baby bottle sterilizer for cleaning. Consensus: 'best airway clearance routine is one you will do.'

tips.tip: Living near bodies of water requires nuanced understanding: ocean water NTM-free (3% salt concentration), but estuaries (mixed fresh/salt water like Chesapeake/Delaware/Hudson River) have high NTM from fresh water inputs - distance/wind direction matter for aerosol exposure
tips.notes: Dr. Joseph Falkinham (Virginia Tech microbiologist): 'Ocean water doesn't have any NTM; we tested that. NTM grows in 1% and 2% salt but not 3% salt (ocean concentrations). Walk on beach and inhale salty, NTM-free aerosols. Stay away from estuaries - high numbers of NTM due to inputs of fresh NTM laden waters. Rivers have NTM. Only ocean lacks NTM.' Patient lived most life 'within shell's toss of ocean or spring-fed lake,' infection-free 5 years. Aerosols from estuaries travel depending on wind strength/direction, dilute with distance. N95 mask protects from aerosolized NTM. Jersey shore ocean OK, lagoons/bays risky.

tips.tip: Patients with cavities face more urgent treatment decisions - medical consensus: cavities require treatment ASAP vs nodular disease can sometimes watch-and-wait, though some asymptomatic cavity patients still choose aggressive AC over immediate antibiotics
tips.notes: Patient with BE + MAC + single lower lobe cavity seeking guidance. Doctor: 'once you have cavity, need to treat ASAP.' Patient in 2v3 trial (Arikayce + Ethambutol + Azithromycin, no Rifampin) with cavity tolerated 10 months fine. Another patient: upper lobe cavities, started Arikayce + Azithromycin + Ethambutol + Rifampin after 12 years MAC-free. Patient with MAC/BE/cavity (1.8cmâ†’0.6cm after 4 months treatment): started antibiotics August 2024, pulmonologist recommended segment surgery for small cavity. Another waited 6 months trying AC before treating. Quality vs quantity decision: 'nobody says thank god I waited,' irreversible lung damage scarier than antibiotic side effects.

tips.tip: MAC chimaera subspecies easier to treat/cure than other MAC variants - patients with clean CT scans but positive cultures face uncertainty whether to treat, bronchoscopy can identify infection location (bronchus vs lung parenchyma) for treatment decisions
tips.notes: Patient 2 of 3 sputa positive for M. chimaera, coughing blood 11 months, clearing throat constantly, but 2 separate CT scans 8 months apart completely clean (no nodules, cavities, bronchiectasis). Pulmonologist + ID doctors uncertain whether to treat. Patient from NJH presentation: 'Chimaera one of mycobacteria easier to actually cure.' Doctor suggested MAC possibly in bronchus not lung parenchyma. Patient also has severe acid reflux, blood possibly from esophagus not lungs. Recommendation: consult NJH by telemedicine from Hawaii, consider bronchoscopy to identify infection location. NAC (n-acetyl cysteine) twice daily evidence-based to thin secretions. Some throat symptoms from Sjogren's Syndrome.

tips.tip: Outdoor active lifestyle compatible with NTM management: patients hike, bike, camp, kayak, travel National Parks with camper vans - portable nebulizers, masking for dust/waterfalls, avoiding hot tubs/indoor water mist, spring water for drinking/cleaning equipment
tips.notes: RV/camper van travelers report: portable battery nebulizers (OMRON NE-U100 with AA batteries, Pari S Trek rechargeable), 12v inverter for dry camping, power bank, boil spring water to rinse nebulizer, .2 micron shower filter (or turn water off while soaping - no running shower), masks for dusty trails/waterfalls, avoid brackish water (retention ponds, canals). Florida Trail would need heavy masking. Trader Joe's spring water jugs. Life not over: 73-year-old just back from 6-week RV trip, 72-year-old went Machu Picchu/Galapagos/Grand Canyon/Bryce/Zion, patients regularly camp. Risk management vs isolation - balance quality of life with precautions.

tips.tip: Patient stories and advocacy crucial for medication access: ICER (Institute for Clinical and Economic Review) collects patient/caregiver stories during medication review process to understand disease burden and guide fair pricing/access decisions for new bronchiectasis treatments
tips.notes: ICER announced review of brensocatib for non-CF bronchiectasis (March 2025) - shown in trials to reduce exacerbations and slow lung function decline. ICER collects patient stories during 'scoping phase' (concluded March 31st) to understand: impact on daily life, impact on caregivers, experience with current therapies, hopes for new treatment. Goal: reflect patient priorities and outcomes, promote fair pricing and access. Patient submitted emotional story 'hopeful we can impact if brensocatib gets approved - we need something to reach for.' Stories valued regardless of current lung infection status - ICER needs varied perspectives on bronchiectasis burden (physical, emotional, social, economic).

tips.tip: 2v3 study (two-drug arm without Rifampin: Ethambutol + Azithromycin/Clarithromycin) offers gentler treatment option - patients report better tolerance than Big 3, though sputum conversion may take longer (12+ months), Arikayce added at 6 months if not converting
tips.notes: Patient in 2v3 study randomized to 2-drug group (no Rifampin) on drugs since March 2023, still positive March 2024 (12 months). Works full-time, struggles with fatigue from drugs despite being physically strong. Rifampin 'seems to be one people have hardest time with.' Another patient in same trial: sputum didn't convert after 6 months, doctor added Arikayce at that point without eliminating from trial, sputum converted and stayed clear since May 2022. Patient on 2-drug: switched from Azithromycin to Clarithromycin due to severe diarrhea + tinnitus, got rash on trunk/chest, then tried Clari. Study allows treatment intensification while remaining enrolled.

tips.tip: Natural immunity approaches (vitamins, supplements, chiropractic recommendations) lack clinical evidence for NTM - many supplements toxic at high doses especially fat-soluble vitamins A/D/E/K, consult NJH nutritionist Michelle MacDonald instead of alternative practitioners
tips.notes: Patient tried 4 months vitamins A/D/C/E + selenium + natural meds on chiropractor advice after Big 3 failed + 7 weeks IV Amikacin caused hearing loss. Expert response: 'many supplements toxic including vitamins at higher doses, especially fat-soluble A/D/E/K. Most supplements not clinically proven, healthy diet usually best. Consult Michelle MacDonald nutritionist at NJH by telemedicine (michelle.o.macdonald@gmail.com) who has helped us all, has videos in NTM library. Ask your physician about supplements, not chiro.' Most nodules remain in lungs even after treatment/negative cultures. Weight gain (10%), protein powder, Ensure, Carnation Breakfast Essentials can help - coincidentally patient diagnosed after 4-month gap without protein powder.

tips.tip: Pre-antibiotic TB treatments offer insight for immune support: sunshine/sleep increase immune cells (monocytes, NK cells, interferon), hot/cold hydrotherapy raises immune factors significantly, forest bathing (2-mile daily walks in nature vs urban) boosts immune function per Japanese medical students study
tips.notes: Patient researched pre-antibiotic TB sanitorium treatments: sunshine + sleep increase immune cells (in vitro/in vivo research confirms). Hot/cold therapy (hydrotherapy): hot sauna followed by ice cold bath, intensive care doctor Roger Seheult researches these methods. Wagner-Jauregg won Nobel Prize curing neurosyphilis by inducing fever (gave patients malaria, then quinine to cure malaria). Japanese study: medical students 2-mile daily walk - forest walkers had significant rises in immune cells vs urban walkers ('forest bathing' treatment). Medicine abandoned these immune-boosting approaches in post-antibiotic era. Theoretical benefit but no direct NTM clinical trials.

tips.tip: Good Morning America featured bronchiectasis story but didn't capture daily realities: patients frustrated segment omitted twice-daily ACT, susceptibility to infections, embarrassing coughing/mucus clearing, constant throat clearing - media exposure valuable but incomplete
tips.notes: Linda Esposito (author 'BE CLEAR Method to Living with Bronchiectasis') shared GMA segment. Patients grateful for exposure but disappointed: 'doesn't even come close to describing life with bronchiectasis - no mention of 2x daily ACT, susceptibility to infections, embarrassing coughing and mucus clearing.' Fatigue ('darn tired all the time') omitted. Educational gap: general public/doctors don't understand daily disease burden. Warning: benzonatate (cough suppressant 100mg) NOT good for BE patients - reduces mucus clearance, traps secretions, worsens infection risk. Cough protective. Only use for plane flight/short-term with BE specialist approval.

tips.tip: Perfumes, scented products, aerosol sprays (hairspray, window cleaner, air fresheners) trigger wheezing/coughing in BE/NTM patients - avoid or use with ventilation, frustrating when healthcare professionals wear perfume in medical settings
tips.notes: Patient wheezing from mother's hairspray/scented products as teenager. 'Scented products have no place in medical situation' - nurses wearing perfume problematic. Work with smelly art supplies/cleaning products requires mask or respirator. Patient hires cleaning service every few months for heavy shower scrubbing (Rainx, wall cleaning) due to fume irritation/coughing. Avoid aerosols/mists - window cleaner used with care. Room humidifier with distilled water 'very bad idea' for Arizona patient (learned after diagnosis). Environmental irritants worsen already-compromised airways - protection and not irritating lungs essential for disease management.

tips.tip: Airway clearance definition of 'effective' unclear even to patients - not everyone produces sputum, but non-productive AC still valuable: saline makes lungs less hospitable to NTM, mucus plugs can take weeks to inch out with continued AC, all AC loosens/moves mucus
tips.notes: Patient working full-time struggles producing sputum, questions if AC effective: 'How do we know if making difference or doing properly? Is producing sputum only way to know effective?' Expert responses: (1) Some naturally bigger sputum producers than others, can improve with time/experimentation, (2) Saline makes environment less hospitable to NTM even without sputum production, (3) NJH doctor: mucus plug can take weeks to inch its way out with continued AC, may not get anything out for some time before you do, (4) One expert: 'all airway clearance, even if not productive, loosens and moves mucus around in airways, therefore important to do,' (5) 'Best airway clearance routine is one you will do.' Frees from searching for perfection.

tips.tip: Airway clearance efficiency tips for time-crunched patients: mix 3% + 7% saline (4mL total) if 7% too harsh, use continuous mode instead of breath-actuated for one vial to save time, press green button on AeroEclipse for more saline per inhale, nebulize first then vest/Aerobika separately
tips.notes: Patient took 'almost hour' to nebulize 2 vials 7% saline. Time-saving tips: (1) Adjust AeroEclipse to continuous delivery (not breath-actuated) for at least one vial, (2) Press small green button on top of AeroEclipse for more saline each inhale, (3) Mix 2mL 3% + 2mL 7% if 7% alone too irritating (total 4mL), (4) Use Pari Sprint nebulizer (faster than AeroEclipse, 20 minutes for 7%, goes deeper), (5) Nebulize first, let saline settle in, THEN do vest/Aerobika (Dr. McShane recommendation - not simultaneously), (6) Lay down after nebulizing, inhale/hold 5-7 seconds, gentle release gives urge to cough up mucus. Realistic: one session 20-30 minutes achievable with practice/right equipment.

tips.tip: Patient stable 10 years with BE + MAC (mild, no antibiotics yet) using comprehensive routine: Aerobika with 7% saline + autogenic drainage app (20 minutes 2x/day), guaifenesin 600mg 30-60 minutes before AC, 1-hour aerobic walking daily, postural drainage (30 minutes)
tips.notes: Lavinia Krufka: mild BE + NTM stable 10 years, no drug treatment yet. Protocol: (1) Aerobika with AeroEclipse attached + one vial 7% saline, 20 minutes 2x/day (Ombra compressor, always bit saline remaining on breath-actuated setting is normal), (2) Autogenic drainage app simultaneously (4.5 minutes), (3) Guaifenesin 600mg tablets with water 30-60 minutes before Aerobika, (4) One hour aerobic walking daily after lunch (take 400mg guaifenesin with lunch), (5) Postural drainage afternoon 30 minutes (one hour after second 600mg guaifenesin, before second Aerobika). Total AC time: ~2 hours 10 minutes daily not including cleaning/setup. This year's PFT slightly better than baseline. 'If stayed stable 10 years, have to assume what doing is effective.'

tips.tip: Insurance appeals for out-of-network NTM specialist difficult but possible - Kaiser HMO typically won't refer out (patients self-pay), but some PPOs allow upgrades during open enrollment, continuity of care requests can help if provider contract at risk, specialist letters strengthen appeals
tips.notes: Kaiser HMO Northern/Southern California: will not refer out for NTM specialist even though don't have one, patients self-pay at NJH. Patient with Anthem EPO had to wait year for open enrollment to upgrade to Anthem PPO. Blue Shield PPO California: patient applied for continuity of care request when UC system/Blue Shield contract at risk, approved. Specialist wrote letter supporting continuity request (template valuable for others). NJH in-network for some Illinois plans. Recommendations: (1) Check if provider in-network, (2) Appeal with physician letters documenting lack of in-network expertise, (3) Persistent appeals with documentation often succeed, (4) Multiple physician letters make rejection harder, (5) Insurance broker can help, (6) Consider PPO upgrade at open enrollment. 'Not fair how hard to get care we deserve, keep fighting good fight.'

tips.tip: Newly diagnosed patients describe emotional journey: 'horrified,' 'overwhelmed,' 'depressing,' 'totally turned my world upside down' - but gradual acceptance emerges as learn disease manageable with adaptations, outdoor activities still possible with precautions
tips.notes: 64-year-old asking 'is this over for me? Can I still go hiking, biking, kayaking, National Parks?' Response overwhelming positive: 'Your life as you know it is NOT over. Continue activities but may pace yourself accordingly. Diagnosed 2000, still plays golf, hikes, exercises.' Another: 'Don't panic, use common sense. Went Machu Picchu, Galapagos, Grand Canyon, Bryce, Zion last month. Walk 3 miles daily. All doable with adjustments.' 73-year-old: 'Quality of life vs extreme measures to fight disease with no cure. Just back from 6-week RV trip, took nebulizer every day. I am going to take some precautions and enjoy my life.' Finding balance between risk management and isolation key.

tips.tip: BE/NTM patients emphasize finding medical team experienced in bronchiectasis vital first step (not easy/quick) - complex disease presenting uniquely in each patient, not every physician has deep knowledge needed for optimal care
tips.notes: Mamie Balestra (10 years experience): 'Finding medical team experienced in BE was first, vital step. Wasn't easy or quick, but made all difference in world. Complex disease presenting uniquely in each of us; not every physician has deep knowledge we want.' Patients travel to: NJH Denver, Johns Hopkins, NYU Langone, Northwestern, UCSD, University of Florida, Tyler Texas. New meds like Brensocatib work to disrupt cycle of lung damage/infection/inflammation but until airways regain elasticity/functionality/self-cleaning ability, must commit to 2x daily AC. Recognition: 'I am not my bronchiectasis.' Early on felt disease taking over life. Pattern: adapt/accept, new normal emerges different from old but becomes normal.

key_insights: Success is redefined: not necessarily 'cured forever' but rather 'constant adaptation to what life throws my way' - accepting uncertainty while living fully without letting disease control your life

Working full-time with NTM requires ruthless efficiency: outsource what you can, work from home if possible, batch tasks, cut exercise slightly, accept career may suffer, use AC time for other activities - vest game-changer for working patients

Treatment fear often worse than reality for many (though highly individual) - many patients have minimal side effects, but online reports skewed negative since people without problems don't post success stories
Watch-and-wait valid for asymptomatic/mild disease with aggressive airway clearance - some patients stable 8-10+ years without antibiotics, but requires discipline continuing AC indefinitely
First year after diagnosis hardest emotionally (overwhelming, scary, depressing) - patients go through grief stages before reaching acceptance and adaptation, community support critical
NTM fatigue is debilitating DISEASE symptom not just medication effect - can render patients bedridden for years, improves dramatically with treatment or aggressive AC + exercise over 12-18 months

Diagnostic errors common: NTM patients frequently misdiagnosed as asthma/walking pneumonia, prescribed contraindicated treatments, sometimes dying before correct diagnosis - 1 in 10 diagnoses wrong/delayed/missed per JAMA
Younger working-age patients (50-65) face unique crisis: too young to retire, need insurance, SSD difficult to qualify, financial stress compounds physical demands - career prime years disrupted

Reinfection rates high (less than 30% MAC-free for life) likely due to: underlying bronchiectasis vulnerability, not everyone continues AC post-treatment, environmental bacteria ubiquity, possible dormant bacterial re-emergence

M. abscessus treatment brutal (9 weeks hospital IV + 12-18 months continuation) with high side effect risk (hearing loss) but can work - patient quality of life restored, traveling internationally, swimming 3km 5x/week

common_questions.question: Are there any real success stories - people who cleared NTM and stayed clear long-term?
common_questions.answer: Yes: patients clear 5-8+ years post-treatment (since 2009, 2019). Patient MAC-free since May 2021 after 22 months treatment, normal PFT, stable CT. Another bedridden 2 years with MAC/chimaera, now swimming half mile daily 6 years later. BUT reinfection rates high - Mayo Clinic says less than 30% MAC-free for life. Vulnerability remains due to bronchiectasis. Success redefined as 'adaptation' not necessarily 'permanent cure.' Key: continuing diligent airway clearance post-treatment (doctor says 'very few' do this).

common_questions.question: Can I work full-time while managing NTM?
common_questions.answer: Yes but challenging. Keys: (1) Work from home if possible (huge time saver - no commute/appearance prep), (2) Supportive employer, (3) Ruthless efficiency (outsource laundry/cleaning, Trader Joe's shortcuts, electric car to save gas stops), (4) Batch equipment cleaning while doing other tasks, (5) Get vest qualification (wear while working, no focus needed), (6) Accept career may suffer. Reality: 2-3 hours daily AC, struggle to fit everything, 6 hours sleep, resentment, social life suffers weekdays. ER nurse: 3 hours AC daily on 12-hour shifts, 42-year work ethic, husband helps chores. Being patient is 'literally full-time job' with appointments, phone calls, insurance battles.

common_questions.question: I'm asymptomatic - should I start treatment or watch-and-wait?
common_questions.answer: Valid choice either way - discuss with NTM specialist. Many asymptomatic patients choose watch-and-wait with aggressive airway clearance (nebulizer 2x/day with 7% saline), regular CT monitoring, exercise, weight management. Some stable 8-10+ years without antibiotics. Decision factors: (1) CT severity (mild vs nodules/cavities), (2) Symptoms (fatigue, cough, weight loss), (3) Personal tolerance for medication side effects, (4) Quality of life priorities. 85-year-old told MAC in 60s, never treated, has COPD but 'quite healthy.' 75-year-old chest percussion 2x/day, no drugs, doctor not pushing since CT 'mild.' Watch-and-wait requires discipline continuing AC indefinitely.

common_questions.question: How bad are Big 3 side effects really?
common_questions.answer: Highly individual - ranges from 'no side effects, breezed through' to 'horrible, had to stop.' Many patients have minimal issues: orange pee, tooth discoloration (fixed with hydrogen peroxide rinse), fatigue, itchy skin. Online reports skewed negative - people without problems don't post. Helpful: Ondansetron (Zofran 4mg dissolvable) for nausea during adjustment, take meds at night before bed, switch to every-other-day dosing if daily too much. Factors affecting tolerance: age, general health, genetics (MTHFR), autoimmune conditions, infection load. Get baseline hearing/eye exams, labs every 6-8 weeks. Fear often worse than reality but prepare for possibility of side effects.

common_questions.question: Why do I have such debilitating fatigue?
common_questions.answer: NTM fatigue is disease symptom not just medication effect. Patients describe: bedridden 2 years, unable to empty dishwasher, exhausted after airway clearance. Causes: (1) Active infection, (2) Inflammation from bronchiectasis + NTM, (3) Extra effort breathing, (4) Coinfections (Pseudomonas, Aspergillus). Improves with: (1) Treatment (12-18 months antibiotics), (2) Aggressive airway clearance alone (10 years patient: fatigue went away with regular AC, never treated with drugs), (3) Exercise (pulmonary rehab: 'unable to empty dishwasher to jogging in 6 weeks'). Patient requires 10 hours sleep nightly, believes Pseudomonas causes her fatigue. Exercise transformative even when don't feel like it.

common_questions.question: How long does M. abscessus treatment take and is it worth it?
common_questions.answer: M. abscessus (especially subsp abscessus erm 41 most drug-resistant): 9-week hospital IV intensive phase + 12-18 months continuation phase at home (daily drugs, twice-daily Amikacin nebulizer, monthly check-ins, hearing tests, ECGs, biweekly bloods). High side effect risk including hearing loss (devastating). BUT can work: Patient week 58 treatment, dreadful cough gone, swimming 3km 5x/week, traveling internationally, 'life is good.' Another: 14 months treatment 8 years ago, worked, but reinfected now. Delayed 6 years initially since felt well. Quality of life consideration: treat when symptoms bad enough to warrant risks.

common_questions.question: What if my local pulmonologist missed the diagnosis or told me treatment worse than disease?
common_questions.answer: Diagnostic errors common: JAMA says 1 in 10 diagnoses wrong/delayed/missed. NTM patients frequently misdiagnosed as asthma/walking pneumonia, prescribed contraindicated treatments (steroids worsen NTM). Patient told 'treatment worse than disease' for years while MAC destroyed lingula, told 'didn't look sick.' Pulmonologist at prestigious medical school refused NJH referral claiming equal expertise - patient self-referred. Another personally knows case died from delayed diagnosis. Get second opinion from NTM specialist at Care Center Network: https://www.bronchiectasisandntminitiative.org/Find-Care/Care-Center-Network/Find-a-Center. NJH does 42+ tests local doctors can't do.

common_questions.question: Can I qualify for Social Security Disability with NTM?
common_questions.answer: Difficult - typically requires: (1) Not working 12 months due to condition, (2) Lung function 40% or lower. Many symptomatic patients don't qualify. Patient approved at 61 after being 'let go' due to repeated pneumonia 4-5x/year. Another's application pending over 1 year with repetitive paperwork. Private long-term disability approved then abruptly denied after 3 weeks. Consider: (1) Get doctor letters documenting serious lung + intestinal conditions needing work-from-home (don't specify diagnoses - private), (2) Consult employment attorney about American Disabilities Act rights, (3) Request intermittent leave of absence, (4) Apply for SSD even if think won't qualify - some get approved within 2 months after examination.

common_questions.question: Should I go to National Jewish Health for evaluation?
common_questions.answer: Highly recommended especially if: (1) Local doctors not NTM specialists, (2) Diagnosis unclear or treatment not working, (3) Want comprehensive workup. NJH does 2-week evaluation: 42+ tests including genetic susceptibility causes, strain-specific drug sensitivity testing, evaluation for underlying conditions (CF, RA, immune defects). Patient: 'NJH does far more than CTs/cultures - determines WHY you're susceptible, which medications work with YOUR specific bacteria strands.' Life-long connection ensures best care. Insurance may cover as second opinion. Patient self-referred after prestigious medical school pulmonologist refused referral claiming equal expertise.

common_questions.question: How do I emotionally cope with this diagnosis?
common_questions.answer: First year hardest - overwhelming, scary, depressing. Patients go through stages: denial, shock, anger, grief, gradual acceptance, adaptation. Strategies that help: (1) Community support (this forum, patient groups), (2) Focus on what you love (family, friends, faith, nature, art), (3) Don't let disease define you, (4) Accept what you can control vs can't, (5) 'Constant adaptation to what life throws my way' mindset, (6) Acknowledge it's difficult disease emotionally AND medically - 'can bring strongest person to knees, acknowledgement just as important as pats on back.' (7) Empathy for each other in fight is healing. National Jewish clinicians: 'trying to stay positive and hopeful really helps' - easier said than done but important to try.
